Pierre Schaeffer

Études aux chemins de fer

Pierre Schaeffer, the precursor

We find the first samples around the 50s, at the beginning used in the context of concrete music. Pierre Schaeffer as the leader, used recordings of sounds from everyday life to assemble them and create experimental music.

See more

Concrete music:

Experimental technique of musical composition using recorded sounds as raw material. The technique was developed about 1948 by the French composer Pierre Schaeffer and his associates at the Studio d’Essai (“Experimental Studio”) of the French radio system. The fundamental principle of musique concrète lies in the assemblage of various natural sounds recorded on tape (or, originally, on disks) to produce a montage of sound. During the preparation of such a composition, the sounds selected and recorded may be modified in any way desired—played backward, cut short or extended, subjected to echo-chamber effects, varied in pitch and intensity, and so on. The finished composition thus represents the combination of varied auditory experiences into an artistic unity.

The Beatles, Tomorrow never knows

In 1966 the general public got acquainted with the tape looping process. When the Beatles seize on this technique, the result is revolutionary!

See more

tape looping

In music, tape loops are loops of magnetic tape used to create repetitive, rhythmic musical patterns or dense layers of sound when played on a tape recorder. Originating in the 1940s with the work of Pierre Schaeffer, they were used among contemporary composers of 1950s and 1960s, such as Éliane Radigue, Steve Reich, Terry Riley, and Karlheinz Stockhausen, who used them to create phase patterns, rhythms, textures, and timbres. Popular music authors of 1960s and 1970s, particularly in psychedelic, progressive and ambient genres, used tape loops to accompany their music with innovative sound effects. In the 1980s, analog audio and tape loops with it gave way to digital audio and application of computers to generate and process sound. ____________________________ 'The tape loop idea started because they all had Brennell machines,' - Geoff Emerick sound engineer & record producer of the Beatles 'Paul in particular used the make his own loops at home and walk into the studio with bags full of little reels saying "Listen to this!" The seagull-like noise on "Tomorrow Never Knows" is realy a distorted guitar.' 'We did a live mix of all the loops' - George Martin record producer, arranger, composer, conductor, audio engineer, and musician 'All over the studios we had people spooling them onto machines with pencils while Geoff did the balancing. There were many other hands controlling the panning.' 'We had five machines running,' - Phil McDonald recording studio audio engineer of the Beatles 'Geoff would say "OK, let's lift that fader, that sounds good." It was done totally off the cuff. The control room was as full of loops as it was people.' 'I laid all of the loops onto the multi-track and played the faders like a modern day synthesiser,' - Geoff Emerick sound engineer & record producer of the Beatles

Amen Break, “beat seller”!

The Amen break is a drum sample originally played by G.C. Coleman from The Winstons. 5 seconds without which the jungle and drum’n’bass would never have existed. Hip-hop wouldn't have the same face if the biggest producers hadn't been able to use it.

See more

The Fairlight CMI

The 'Mother' of all samplers. The technology that is today used world wide to compose music using digital samples started with the The Fairlight CMI. Featured on the program 'This Week' from ABC-TV Australia (1980) and is demonstrated by one of the CMI's designers, Pete Vogel and composer Michael Carlos playing his composition of the theme for a proposed ABC-TV sci-fi series "Timewarp" .

Jean Michel Jarre

In 1979, the introduction of the Fairlight CMI line of sampler synthesizers made it possible to edit and modify waveforms on the monitor. With such a machine, the musician can graphically manipulate the parameters of a sound. Jean Michel Jarre is one of the first users, his seventh album Zoolook is distinguished by the use of samples of 25 different ethnic voices as percussion. At the time, the price of a Fairlight was £ 25,000, which is equivalent to £ 25,000 today!

See more

The Fairlight CMI

The 'Mother' of all samplers. The technology that is today used world wide to compose music using digital samples started with the The Fairlight CMI. Featured on the program 'This Week' from ABC-TV Australia (1980) and is demonstrated by one of the CMI's designers, Pete Vogel and composer Michael Carlos playing his composition of the theme for a proposed ABC-TV sci-fi series "Timewarp" .

The SP 1 200, first numeric sampler

The SP-1 200 can store up to 100 patterns, 100 songs, and has a 5,000-note maximum memory for drum sequences. He considerably accentuated the use of Amen Break in musical compositions, by democratizing sampling among music composers.

The conflict, sampling’s limits

The limit of the sample stems from its ethical side, fueling many controversies. Its use is not regulated, disputes are legion. The group The Verve seems to be the perfect example! The track Bitter Sweet Symphony uses an (unauthorized) sample from The Last Time by The Rolling Stones. They were then forced to return 100% of their royalties, it was only recently that The Verve recovered the rights!

See more
